data.description:

Approach 1: National Energy Services Reunited Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes the cash that a company is expected to generate in the future and discounts it back to today to estimate what the entire business could be worth now.

For National Energy Services Reunited, the latest twelve month Free Cash Flow is about $153.0 million. The model used here is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, which first applies analyst forecasts and then extends those cash flows further out using additional assumptions by Simply Wall St.

The projections used in the model include Free Cash Flow of $154.6 million in 2026 and $219.0 million in 2028, with further years out to 2035 based on extrapolated estimates, all in $. When these projected cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $58.38 per share.

Compared with the recent share price of $25.14, this DCF estimate suggests a difference of around 56.9% between the modelled intrinsic value and the current market price.

Result: UNDERVALUED (based on this DCF model)

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests National Energy Services Reunited is undervalued by 56.9%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 54 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for National Energy Services Reunited.

Approach 2: National Energy Services Reunited Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to see how much you are paying for each dollar of earnings. This makes it a useful cross check alongside a DCF model. What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E depends on what the market expects for future earnings growth and how risky those earnings are, with higher expected growth or lower perceived risk usually supporting a higher multiple.

National Energy Services Reunited currently trades on a P/E of about 49.6x. That sits above both the Energy Services industry average of roughly 26.6x and the peer group average of about 32.7x. This suggests the market is applying a richer multiple than these broad comparison points.

Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for the stock is 25.9x. This is a proprietary estimate of what the P/E might be based on factors such as earnings growth, profit margins, industry, market cap and company specific risks. Because it ties the multiple to these fundamentals, the Fair Ratio can offer a more tailored reference point than a simple peer or industry comparison.

When set against the current P/E of 49.6x, the Fair Ratio of 25.9x points to the shares trading on a higher multiple than this framework would suggest.

Result: OVERVALUED

data.description:

Understanding what is already baked into the share price matters if you are trying to work out whether recent moves reflect lasting shifts in expectations or short term trading.

Approach 1: Iovance Biotherapeutics Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of a company‚Äôs future cash flows and discounts them back to today to arrive at an estimate of what the business could be worth right now.

For Iovance Biotherapeutics, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, based on cash flow projections in US$. The latest twelve month free cash flow is a loss of about $343.7 million. Analysts provide forecasts out to 2030, with free cash flow projections moving from a loss of $146 million in 2026 and $13 million in 2027, to positive cash flows of $143 million in 2028, $231 million in 2029 and $313 million in 2030. Beyond the analyst horizon, Simply Wall St extrapolates further free cash flow estimates out to 2035 using its own growth assumptions.

When all of those projected cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $23.63 per share. Compared with the recent share price around $3.79, this implies the stock is about 84.0% undervalued on this measure.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Approach 2: Iovance Biotherapeutics Price vs Sales

For companies that are not yet profitable, the P/S ratio is often more useful than P/E because it compares what investors are paying to the revenue being generated, rather than to earnings that are still negative.

In general, higher expected growth and lower perceived risk can support a higher P/S ratio. Slower growth or higher risk tends to justify a lower one. That is why it helps to look at Iovance Biotherapeutics in the context of both its industry and its own fundamentals.

Iovance Biotherapeutics currently trades on a P/S of 5.93x. This sits below the Biotechs industry average of 12.58x and also below the peer average of 6.82x provided. Putting that together, Iovance Biotherapeutics‚Äô actual P/S of 5.93x is above the Fair Ratio of 4.19x, which points to the shares pricing in a richer multiple than this framework suggests.

Result: OVERVALUED

Hysan Development (SEHK:14) has put fresh numbers on the table for FY 2025, with first half revenue at HK$1,838 million and basic EPS of HK$0.07. This sets the tone after a mixed FY 2024 that saw revenue move from HK$1,613 million to HK$1,713 million, while EPS shifted between HK$0.42 and a loss of HK$0.38. Over the trailing 12 months, revenue ranged between HK$3,326 million and HK$3,551 million, with EPS moving from HK$0.03 to HK$0.31. HK$900m one off swings margin picture

  • Trailing 12 month net income excluding extra items sits at HK$840 million on HK$3,464 million of revenue, and that comes alongside a HK$900 million one off loss that materially shaped the reported 24.2% net margin versus 1.1% last year.
  • Bulls argue that projects like Lee Garden Eight and the wider Lee Gardens ecosystem can support higher recurring rental income and margins. However, the size of that HK$900 million item and the move from a loss of HK$317 million in the prior 12 months to HK$840 million now means part of the earnings jump reflects clean up effects rather than just ongoing rental strength.

  • At a share price of HK$21.82, the trailing P/E of 26.7x sits well above both peers at 14.2x and the wider Hong Kong real estate industry at 14.4x, while earnings are forecast to grow about 21.2% per year and revenue is forecast at 3.7% annual growth versus 8.6% for the market.

    • If you prefer to stress test that view, you might compare the current premium multiple and DCF fair value gap with what you would expect given revenue growth that is below the 8.6% market forecast.
On a strong earnings growth story priced at a 26.7x P/E, some investors want to see exactly how bullish analysts think this can go before they decide how to weigh that premium. üêÇ Hysan Development Bull Case

Debt coverage and dividend pressure

  • The company offers a 4.95% dividend yield, yet dividends are flagged as not well covered by earnings and debt is described as not well covered by operating cash flow, which makes the balance sheet a key watchpoint alongside the income stream.
  • Bears highlight that weaker debt coverage and reliance on instruments like perpetual securities can leave less headroom if rental conditions stay tough, and the data here backs their focus because cash flow coverage of debt and dividend payout are both identified as pressure points rather than strengths.
    • Critics also note that while trailing margins look strong at 24.2%, that sits beside concerns about refinancing costs and the need to keep funding projects like Lee Garden Eight and other developments.
    • If you are weighing the cautious view, the combination of a near 5% yield, limited earnings cover, and flagged debt coverage risk gives you a clear list of financial items to track in the next few reporting periods.

data.title: HP Q1 Beat Highlights AI PC Momentum And Memory Cost Challenge
data.description:
• HP Inc. (NYSE:HPQ) reported fiscal Q1 2026 results with Personal Systems net revenue growth and AI PCs making up more than one third of shipments.
  • The company faced a sharp jump in memory costs, roughly doubling over the quarter, which pressured margins.
  • Management responded with cost mitigation moves, including product redesigns, supply agreements, and selective pricing actions, while continuing to return capital to shareholders.

For investors watching NYSE:HPQ, the latest quarter pairs operational pressure with clear traction in AI PCs. The stock trades at $18.81 and is down 15.0% year to date and 40.7% over the past year, reflecting a tough stretch despite the progress in newer product categories.

Looking ahead, the key questions for you are how effectively HP manages elevated memory costs and whether AI PC demand remains strong enough to support margins. The company‚Äôs focus on redesigning products, adjusting pricing, and locking in supply terms will be central to how these Q1 trends develop over the coming quarters.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for HP by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on HP.

See which insiders are buying and buying and selling HP following this latest news.

For current and prospective shareholders, this Q1 update sends a mixed but useful signal. On one hand, HP outperformed expectations on both revenue and EPS, with net revenue of US$14.4b compared to US$13.5b a year earlier and non GAAP EPS above consensus. On the other, operating income fell and management is guiding toward the lower end of its full year earnings ranges as DRAM and NAND costs pressure margins. That combination often leads to short term share price weakness, which you are already seeing. However, it also gives you clearer information on how management plans to handle higher input costs through product re configuration, supplier diversification and selective price increases. The fact that HP maintained its fiscal 2026 GAAP EPS range of US$2.47 to US$2.77 while outlining a US$1b cost savings plan suggests management is trying to balance investment in AI PCs with disciplined capital returns, including US$0.6b returned in Q1 and continued buybacks. Against a backdrop of insider share sales and mixed institutional flows, this quarter is likely to be read as a test of whether HP can convert strong AI PC demand into durable earnings power rather than just a one off beat.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The HP Narrative

  • The strong Q1, with AI PCs at more than one third of shipments and Personal Systems growth, supports the narrative that AI driven PCs and premium devices can underpin revenue and margin resilience.
  • The sharp rise in memory costs and guidance toward the low end of EPS ranges challenges the view that cost restructuring alone can fully offset input cost pressure and structural headwinds in Print.
  • The specific memory cost inflation and the US$1b mitigation plan through FY2028 add more detail on cost risks and timing that are only partially reflected in the existing narrative about restructuring and supply chain diversification.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider
